messages.subject: Re: real world
messages.msgSnippet: ... *************************** What does he like to do? Does he want responsibilities? What does that mean to him? Babysitting? Or working under the table for
messages.messageBody:
--- In unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com, "Sandy Stephan" <sandy@...> wrote:
>
> I need suggestions for my 11 year old son to get out into the real world with responsibilities. He's ready for a change We are 20 min. from Berkeley in El Sobrante. Any suggestions I can present to him?
***************************

What does he like to do? Does he want responsibilities? What does that mean to him? Babysitting? Or working under the table for a landscaper or a craftsperson, maybe? I don't know anything about your area, but is there agricultural work available?

Is he simply bored and looking for new directions? I'm always a little leery when a parent new to an unschooling list says either "real world" or "responsibilities" - its often about the parent's agenda moreso than the kid's. Radical unschooling happens in the real world, already. There are real problems to solve daily - even problems like "what am I going to do today?" (that's time management).

---Meredith (Mo 7, Ray 15)

messages.subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] real world
messages.msgSnippet: I m not sure I understand the question. What exactly are you looking for? Is he in school? What responsibilities does he want?  ~Kelly Kelly Lovejoy There is

I'm not sure I understand the question.



What exactly are you looking for?




Is he in school? What responsibilities does he want?


 ~Kelly

Kelly Lovejoy
"There is no single effort more radical in its potential for saving the world than a transformation of the way we raise our children." Marianne Williamson

messages.subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] real world
messages.msgSnippet: What is it he likes to or wants to do? My dd started volunteering young. She has volunteered at a bookstore, soup kitchen, free store and animal rescue. She
messages.messageBody:
What is it he likes to or wants to do? My dd started volunteering
young. She has volunteered at a bookstore, soup kitchen, free store
and animal rescue. She had tried to start her own pet walking service,
still trying.
Those are just a few ideas to help you get started.

Faith

Sent from my iPhone

messages.messageBody:
I need suggestions for my 11 year old son to get out into the real world with responsibilities. He's ready for a change We are 20 min. from Berkeley in El Sobrante. Any suggestions I can present to him?
Thanks in advance,
Sandy
